column1: Data Export Generated on Tue Aug 03 15:48:07 PDT 2021

column19: Hi there! Thank you very much for your time.We really appreciate it. Please please help us understand corporate behavior answering this short survey. We'd love to pay you for completing this task and will surely do it as long as you answer to the best of your knowledge. We know you will answer in this fashion as you are too cool to answer in a rush or not paying attention to the questions ;)
column20: Consent Form1.      What is the study about?You are invited to participate in a study of consumer behavior. We hope to learn how companies are perceivedby consumers after they engage in certain kinds of corporate behavior. Our intention is to understand someof the factors that influence these perceptions. To gain insights on these perceptions multiple-choice questionswill be asked about certain aspects of the behavior of the companies.Answers will then be analyzed to gain insights on how consumers perceive the companies.2.       Do I have to participate?Being part of this study is voluntary. If you want to be part of the study we ask that you read the information below carefully.You can read the information below and decide at the end if you do not want to participate.  3.       Who is being asked to participate?You have been asked to participate because:·         You are part of a society where contact with organizations is frequent. 4.       What will I be asked to do?If you want to take part in this study we will ask you to read a short vignette (or a set of them) and answer a short questionnaireregarding it (them). It will take around 10 minutes of your time to be part of this study. You will receive a compensation of 0.4 after completing the survey in its totality.5.       What are the benefits?The benefit of you taking part in this study is that you will contribute to research on consumer behavior. The expected benefits to society in general are a better understanding of how consumers think about organizations. 6.       What are the risks?With any study there are (1) risks we know about (2) risks we don’t know about and (3) risks we don’t expect.If you experience something that you aren’t sure about please contact us immediately so we can discuss the best way to manage your concerns.           Name: Luis Arango Email: laarangoso@unal.edu.co       We have listed the risks we know about below. This will help you decide if you want to be part of the study.·         You can experience some distress upon reading the description of the scenario(s).7.       What will happen to information about me?By clicking on the ‘I agree start questionnaire’ button this tells us you want to take part in the study.We will collect information about you in ways that will not reveal who you are.We will store information about you in ways that will not reveal who you are. We will publish information about you in ways that will not be identified in any type of publication from this study.We will keep your information indefinitely after the project is completed and might use it for future related projects.The data will be available publicly so that other researchers can replicate the findings.  Notice that no personal information that can identify you will be collected in this study. The personal information you provide will be handled in accordance with applicable privacy laws any health information collected will be handled in accordance with the Health Records Act 2001 (Vic). Subject to any exceptions in relevant laws you have the right to access and correct your personal information by contacting the research team.8.       Will I hear about the results of the study?We will let you know about the results of the study by email upon request to the principal investigator. Please consider that it can take several months before this research is published.9.       What if I change my mind?If you no longer want to complete the questionnaire simply close the web browser.If you change your mind after clicking on the ‘Submit’ button we cannot withdraw your responses because we cannot link who you are with your questionnaire responses. 10.    Who can I contact for questions or want more information?If you would like to speak to us please use the contact details below:Name: Luis Arango Email: laarangoso@unal.edu.co  Consent Form –Declaration by ParticipantI (the participant) have read understood the Participant Information Statement and any questions have been answered to my satisfaction. I agree to participate in the study I know I cannot withdraw my responses following the collection of my data but that I can abandon the survey at any point during the completion of it. I agree information provided by me or with my permission during the project may be included in a thesis presentation and published in journals on the condition that I cannot be identified. I also understand that my responses to the questionnaire will be part of a data set that will be publicly available and that the dataset can be used for any future studies.If you wish to receive a copy of the study results you can request it by contacting Mr Luis Alfredo Arango at laarangoso@unal.edu.co. The results are expected to be available around November 2022. This long period is due to the duration of academic journals’ peer-review processes.
column24: What is your highest degree or level of school you have completed?
column27: Please read carefully the following scenario as ALL the questions make reference to it: Crimson One is an American construction business that builds residential properties in the USA. The business has around 300 employees. Crimson One has been operating for over ten years and its financial situation is very good. One day Crimson One owners decide to increase their profits and start employing cheaper materials to construct houses in low-income suburbs where it can go unnoticed. Similar strategies have been widely implemented across the industry for the last months by other USA companies. Crimson One owners decide to follow suit and do the same even though they don’t need to do this in order to continue being profitable and competitive. The strategy is a success for Crimson One and the business owners decide to stick with it. However many American homeowners and tenants are eventually impacted by the use of cheap materials and they later find themselves spending money on house maintenance and repairs.
column29: Crimson One behavior is rare in the industry.
column30: Crimson's cheap material strategy was not profitable.
column31: What do you think about the behavior of Crimson One?
column32: You will be presented with some statements. Please choose your level of agreement with the statements using the options given.
column33: Here is a reminder of the scenario in case you need it. Please take into account that all the questions will make reference to it:  Crimson One is an American construction business that builds residential properties in the USA. The business has around 300 employees. Crimson One has been operating for over ten years and its financial situation is very good. One day Crimson One owners decide to increase their profits and start employing cheaper materials to construct houses in low-income suburbs where it can go unnoticed. Similar strategies have been widely implemented across the industry for the last months by other USA companies. Crimson One owners decide to follow suit and do the same even though they don’t need to do this in order to continue being profitable and competitive. The strategy is a success for Crimson One and the business owners decide to stick with it. However many American homeowners and tenants are eventually impacted by the use of cheap materials and they later find themselves spending money on house maintenance and repairs.
column58: Please write a random six digit number (don't be predictable for example 123456" as this would be used to pay you). Please place the same code on Mturk when prompted."

column31: To increase profitability and little chance of being punished.
I dislike that many companies do this in the industry, however I understand why Crimson One does it.

The behavior of Crimson One is an unfortunate result of the business owners choosing short term profits over longer-term, more valuable customer satisfaction and referrals. The American homeowners and tenants now have to fix the building materials out of their own pocket while Crimson One reaps all the profits. This is an unfortunate situation that should be redressed in the courts by the homeowner and tenants making a case against Crimson One.
I think the behavior of Crimson One is selfish.

While I don't like it - based on the scenario, the behavior had evolved into a somewhat standard behavior for the industry.  Based on this, I understand why they made the decision they did.  At the same time, they could have promoted themselves by marketing initiatives making known the fact that they use higher quality materials than some competitors.  This alone may have increased their profitability because many consumers are interested in quality.  And based on the scenario, they were profitable prior to moving to lower quality materials, which makes me frown on them all the more.  Seems their move to inferior quality materials was based on greed.
I think it's unethical and unfair to do what they did just for their own profit. They are untrustworthy and not a company I would want to work with.
The company CEO/mgmt needs to be fined and sent to jail.

I think that this type of behavior is uncalled for. If a person is buying a home then the construction company should build that home using the best materials. It takes most people at least 30 years to pay for their home, and this construction wants to cut corners just for a profit. In my opinion home should take these types of construction companies to court when they use cheap materials.

I honestly expect no less from a company that is successful. If a company can find a way to cut corners and costs so they profit from it, then they will do it. I think it's unfortunate too since Crimson One using cheaper materials ends up costing the homeowners in the long run, specifically the ones with low income. They'll have a much harder time repairing anything because they lack the money.
I think it’s unethical and money grabbing. And selfish, to boot.

I think Crimson One's behavior is immoral and unethical and they should be ashamed of themselves. They should be held accountable. The people they are selling to are buying in good faith that they are getting a sound product.
I think it's reprehensible and based on greed.
Its corrupt.
Terrible.  They are defrauding customers.

I think it was an unnecessary risk.  It also is unfair and unethical to the home owners who then later have to repair the cheap materials.  If the homeowners found out about the use of cheaper materials, they may have grounds for a lawsuit.
I think their behavior is awful.
Their behavior is unethical and preys upon the economically vulnerable in order to increase its profit margin.
It is wrong. They need to do things right to begin with. This practice will give them a bad reputation which could hurt business.
It's simple greed

I don't like it and I disapprove. It's nasty behavior to cheat people like that, especially when they don't even need to do it to stay competitive since they were already successful and making money, but even if they weren't, it would still be unethical and morally wrong to do it.
I think that it is highly immoral but I know that most construction companies are like this now in our society
Horrible yet sadly typical in this day and age. Quality is pretty much a thing of the past.
I think it makes sense that a US business would do such acts..I think its wrong but it makes sense .
I believe it was unethical.

I understand they are doing what is best for their business and do think it is fair because other businesses are doing the same. However, I do think it would have been great for them to keep their materials cheaper, it would increase loyalty with customers.
It is definitly wrong to do this.
It fits right in with the way the American capitalist society is going. Many companies are employing this same method across all areas of life. It is disheartening and should be illegal.
Cutting corners to make a quick buck wasn't necessary. They could have gone the route advertising their quality construction. They've taken the opportunity to make themselves average.

Bad idea. Any short term profit will eventually result in complaints and potential lawsuits down the line. Not to mention that it's a low-life thing to do - and completely unnecessary for the solvency and success of the company.
I feel this is deplorable but common in the industry.

I believe that they are just following suit of the other companies and trying to maximize their profits. I do not see any harm in this as I'm sure most construction companies, as mentioned in the article do the same thing. It is more costly for the consumer down the road, however profitability wise, they did was any company would choose to do.
very unprofessional

I think it was shady. Even though other companies may be doing the same, a company should pride themselves in not following suite and not engaging in shady business practices to make more money. Especially when it will cost the people who buy these homes more money in the long run.
Totally unprofessional for their personal gain. Untrustworthy to homeowners.
I think it is wrong

I feel this behavior is dishonest and unfair. The company was already profitable without resorting to shady tactics. Everyone deserves to receive the quality product they are paying for. It is regrettable that the homeowners end up paying the repair costs.
It is standard in this day and age for businesses. I think it's disgusting and everything wrong with our society and systems. Profit is not more important than people.

At the end of the day, it is  nothing personal, just business.  It is not fair to judge one when so many others do the same.  Purchasing, being gifted, or provided with free housing does not consist of the best of the best or permanent.  It is temp to get you to your next level.
I think Crimson One was trying to follow the trend in its industry.
Predictable for a bigger business to try to reduce costs

I think the behavior of Crimson One is unfortunate and morally wrong. It makes sense that they would do it because they are in a capitalist society that values profit over people, but it was the wrong thing to do.

Deplorable. They're already making a good profit, there's no need to make American homeowners suffer just to line their own pockets a little more. This is how we get into issues like the Surfside condo collapse.

I think it represents that companies value profits over people.  I feel that they should try to make a profit, but doing so in a way that negatively affects those in low income areas is reprehensible.  You can see in most industries how products now seem to have a short life span.  My mother's washer and dryer lasted decades and today the new fancy machines seem to crap out after a few years.  It is that same mentality for newer homes.  Build them cheap and quick to make more money, screw the homeowners.
it's bad
It was cheap and greedy. The don't care about the customer.
I feel their behavior was shameful and a true detriment to their customers.
Max the profits.
I think it's typical of a big business to try and take the cheaper route so they can spend less money. I don't agree with doing this at all because it hurts the employees and the consumers.

I think it's horrible because it's not only dangerous, it also is unfair to people that are already having a hard time. It's disgusting that they would do this to people just because they know they won't face consequences due to the area.
I think it was a greedy move to use cheap materials.
I think its short sighted, sure they will be able to make a profit in the short term however long term I believe their reputation will be hurt when people realize they build subpar buildings.

It was immoral.  Although others in the industry do as well, Crimson One was generating a profit previous to its new strategy.  They didn't need to take this action.  It was strictly for profit and they knew the materials were substandard.
It is very sad that they are willing to sacrifice quality for their own profit, but I can see why many companies do it.
The behavior is detestable.
This is unethical and immoral behavior. They are hurting people financially in the long run, and they are hurting the people who can least afford the financial hurt.

This is quite common and unfortunately, most people don't know the difference when hiring a contractor and the difference between materials.  They're just concerned about cost and will sacrifice quality for a better price only to find down the line that things start falling apart.  Then they blame the contractor when they're the ones who made the decision originally.  Terrible because whoever buys the home later will end up with an inferior product.
I think that it is unethical especially as they are primarily targeting low-income housing, as this population has little means to perform repairs and speak out against them.
I think it’s poor ethically
I think it is unethical and although they think they got away with using cheaper materials in low income areas I believe what they did will eventually come to light.
its total greed and its terrible
it is common and despicable. no integrity.
I think that it’s contemptible
I think that Crimson One is not trustworthy and they are only out for themselves and do not care about the negative impact this change will have on it's customers.
I think it was unethical but not surprising.
This is a typical scenario common in most, if not all, consumer orientated businesses today. It will lead to the degradation of society.

I think their behavior is a widely used practice, but I also think it's terrible. Poor people already struggle to make ends meet, and their sub-standard materials will cost poor people more money in repairs. Since they were successful (turned a profit) with high quality materials, I would love to see them continue using high quality materials. Unfortunately I think most businesses are out to make the most money and will cut corners when possible.
This kind of behavior perpetrated by companies is appalling and disgusting.
The executives have decided to become greedy and put profits foremost.

It is typical of American business. The goal of the company is to make as much money as possible and enrich the owners. They will lie, cheat, and do anything they can, legal and illegal to increase their wealth and steal from the general public.
I think it is deplorable. They should not do these shortcuts and using cheap materials on anyone, especially those with the least means.
I think it is shameful. I am sick of companies only caring about profit. You can both be concerned about profit and safety and look out for people.
They have the freedom to do this, but I don't like it. They can make as much as they want, but if the products are shoddy then it should be noted.
It was greedy and unnecessary. They will probably now pay for it later with law suits and other issues.
I would say they are a horrible company that only cares about the bottom dollar and not sending out a quality product.  They don't care about their image for the future.
It was justifiable given the houses are considered low income and lower cost therefore lower quality.
Crimson is cheap product buy this is not a good quality for Crimson .
Crimson One behavior was unethical which I believe will impact them in the long run.
Immoral
I think their behavior is unethical and dishonest.
I think that the behavior is selfish and the pinnacle of capitalism, valuing maximum profit over quality of life for american people.

On the one hand, they are building low income housing, which is good.  On the other hand, if the materials used are too cheap the houses won't stand up properly and will end up being more expensive for the homeowners in the long run.

I think that Crimson One's behavior was not moral, ethical, or the right the to do. I think it was wrong of Crimson One to start employing cheaper materials in the low income suburbs, and it was also deceiving of them to knowingly do it in hopes of not being noticed. However, I think Crimson One was more inclined to participate in this behavior because of the similar strategies that had been implemented across the industry. Therefore, even though I think Crimson One was wrong for their behavior and should take responsibility, I think pressure from other similar strategies in the industry caused them to do something they otherwise might not have done.
It is very unethical and unfair to the lower income people. It is greedy.
It is unethical and wrong.

I think it is wrong to do what Crimson One is doing.  Just because they can build cheaper homes for less income people why would they?  The poor people have enough problems they do not need house worries too
I think their choices will end up costing them more money which will make them see less profit
I think it's unethical
Disappointing but typical and unsurprising. Profits are more important than anything else.

I think it's horrible for Crimson One to do this when they don't have to.  It's so unethical, especially to do this to low income people. They are probably so happy when they get to move into a new place and then find out later that they have been duped. Also, all the money they have to spend on repairs.

I think it's pretty shady, personally. If you're already a profitable company, why cut costs lower at the risk of your integrity? That is something so few companies have now and I think it's really important.
I think it's awful, unfair and immoral.
This is terrible, charge the rich more not the poor. This is a massive problem with the world, grinding the poor to dust to extract resources from them.
A very unfair business practice.

I think that it is a little bit questionable.  I think the use of the cheap materials, while allowing the company to be profitable, has negative impact on homeowners down the line as they have to pay for major repairs on their homes.

It's greedy and will end up costing them more in the long run when their reputation suffers and people move away from using them to using companies that use higher quality materials. I also think they're kind of jerks for skimping on quality in low-income areas and making the people that live in their shoddy homes suffer and have to pay more money to fix their on-purpose behavior.
It is unethical
Its not ethical to do, but like many businesses, they cut costs where they can and this happens anyway.
It is criminal at worst, sad at best but unfortunately how many builders work.

It is abhorrent that a company would screw over low income people who probably scrimped and saved for years for a house and can not afford these repairs. It is even more hateful to only do this to low income people especially when they would not be able to afford the eventual repairs. This company is hateful and greedy.
I think it is unethical because that will put more strain on the homeowners or landlords to keep repairing their homes.

I think it's bad.  They were already making a profit and were successful.  This move just screws over people who already have a hard time affording homeownership and then they use cheap materials that cause them to spend money on repairs.
I think it is unfair and unreasonable to take advantage of the poorer people by using low grade materials.

the behavior is irresponsible as subpar materials will result in lower quality products that require more maintenance and repairs.  this is shday and greedy and not putting the needs of the customer first.

I think it's scummy, but not surprising. Capitalism is basically about maximizing profits to the detriment of all else. It doesn't matter what's best for the consumer unless it's also best for the bottom line.
No big thoughts. They just did what everyone else was doing.
It's unfortunately typical of big companies. Not even just in construction, though it's definitely worse to build crappy homes. But, companies are always looking for ways to shave off a penny.
i think they are trying to save money

I think it is very unethical behavior for two main reasons. First, the company was already profitable before deciding to start using poorer quality materials to build homes. Second, it is especially wrong to use these poor materials on low-income homes, as these residents are probably not able to afford the inevitable repairs they will need to make to the property.
I think it is very irresponsible and unethical to target low income people.
I do not like it. If the company continues to be profitable with top of line materials, then they should continue to use them and not go along with what other companies do in using cheaper items.
It's immoral and unethical to me. Very discriminatory to the less fortunate
Very self-serving but I suppose typical. Companies do try to keep their costs low and profits high as a rule.
I think  it is immoral and unacceptable for them to do this, especially when they didn't even need the extra profits to be a profitable company.
I think it is deplorable and despicable
It's a terrible thing to do. There's no quality anymore. People pay a lot for a house and they should get good quality.
While typical in the industry, their approach is one that is unethical - it focuses on their bottom line rather than the well-being of future occupants.
I think they are not a good company and only care about money. They seem selfish.
typical for a lot of businesses, profit before all else, consequences for others be damned
It is a smart business move but not good for their clientele.
They are a horrible company.
Its horrible to do that to people, especially when you don't have to or need to.
I think it is a lame decision from a greedy company.
I think it has great potential to build a great future
shady, immoral.
I think its a company that generates a lot of income and is trustworthy. This company cares mostly about its profits as do most business in the US.
